post.body: ZeroNet technical question: are all ZeroNet sites public in the same way that all Bitcoin transactions are public, or can I create a private zite and only have it be accessible by people who know the link to it?

Why does ZeroNet seem to be so popular in China as opposed to the other darknets? I haven't browsed many different zites but the ones I'm active on seem to have almost as many Chinese speakers as English speakers, and that is definitely not the case with Tor, i2p, etc. Is there some kind of technical limitation to those that ZeroNet doesn't have?

comment.body: No sir! There are more of us out here. What do you like to do? Tell us about yourself!
@Polar: How do I access ZeroNet via i2p? Would I have to use some type of inproxy or does ZeroNet natively support connection through i2p?

@0x01: I'm a hobbyist programmer and a huge darknet enthusiast. Are you any good at front end design for websites? I'm good at back end design and great at setting up (hypothetically) secure hidden services, but I'm no artist. I've got a few community projects I'd like to work on. Do you want to help?
Followup question: When I sign and publish a site, then visit it in my browser, ZeroNet notifies me that my site has been published to 5/5 peers. Who, if anyone, is it being published to?
ZeroVoat is great, but will it ever be possible to create our own channels? The site appears to either be broken or the functionality to create channels has been removed.

@U53r: This is an interesting proposition but I don't think it'll go anywhere. Security through open sourcing is only possible if the authors of a given piece of code actually keep it up to date. I can't speak for your government, but my government has a terrible reputation for paying lots of money for shitty Swiss cheese code, and open sourcing that wouldn't do much except for make it easier for malicious actors to find vulnerabilities in it.
Stay off of ZN, you degenerate filth
@Parziva1 Hi stranger! How are you today? Tell us about yourself.

@Clemantis I just see a blank image. I think what you saw (5 reshares) was just you publishing this blank image to your peers. I'm not sure why whatever picture you uploaded would be blanked out as it was uploaded though.

The fees for monero are fairly high compared to most of the other altcoins, but the baked in privacy is worth it in my opinion. It's got good adoption in the darknet markets which, imo, will probably mean a rise in value over time as more of them move to accept it.

On the topic of Visa cards, does anyone know if there's a Monero Visa card yet? Also, are the BTC (and other altcoin Visas) still locked to certain countries? Last I checked they only had them in a handful of more progressive nations and they weren't available elsewhere.
@xyzyx Hi stranger! Tell us about yourself.
Make it take off! Share it with as many people as you can find that will listen.
I get on most days, but most of the time I just lurk. There's not a lot here yet. Spread the word to others and make the community more active!
@zerocateuadmin: It's great to see you keeping the community... clean, for lack of a better word. Thanks for what you're doing.
